headline.main: Like Other Monthlies, Esquire Dances to a New Rhythm

lead_paragraph: On Sept. 11, David Granger, the editor in chief of Esquire, was about to ship the last few pages of his November issue when terrorists attacked America. Staring at a mockup of the cover -- a photo of the actress Cameron Diaz -- Mr. Granger knew that three weeks later, when the issue reached newsstands and mailboxes, it would seem ''wrong,'' he said, ''that Esquire would be represented to the world by that cover.'' Mr. Granger faced the same challenge as all his peers editing monthly general-interest magazines. With life changing underfoot, and an unwieldy lead time (three weeks between finishing the pages and distributing the issues), he needed to be somehow newsworthy and a must-read.
abstract: Esquire, like other monthly general-interest magazines, is facing challenge of adapting to new realities; plans to mix lighter pieces with articles shaped by events of Sept 11 and its aftermath; photos (M)
